comments.body:
Are you sure that numbers are allowed here? I think header values are always strings (or array of strings in case the same header name is set several times).
In case numbers are really allowed I would expect that also an array of numbers is allowed.

Numbers are allowed as input, see the type of the Content-Length header in the example; https://nodejs.org/api/http.html#http_response_writehead_statuscode_statusmessage_headers

Everything that can be converted to a primitive value is technically valid input.

I just gave this a try and it works. And it has side effects to `getHeader()` typings because if you pass in a `number` in `setHeader()` or `writeHead()` you get a `number` via `getHeader()` - not a `string`.
Also arrays of numbers are allowed and even arrays with mixture of strings and numbers - or everything else which can be appended to a string...
So in then end we are back to `any` in this area - or we force users to stringify in usercode....

I have added number to getHeader. For all normal use cases people don't have to change anything in their code. If they really want to do strange/useless things like adding objects or mixed arrays to header variables then they can cast to make it possible.

Turns out dtslint gets *almost* all the way through definitely typed  before Travis kills it. Searching for errors turns up 1 error in `content-type`: 

```
Testing content-type
	Running: node /home/travis/build/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/node_modules/types-publisher/bin/tester/../../node_modules/dtslint/bin/index.js --noLint
	content-type-tests.ts(14,25): error TS2345: Argument of type 'Response' is not assignable to parameter of type '{ getHeader(key: string): string; }'.
  Types of property 'getHeader' are incompatible.
    Type '(name: string) => string | number | string[]' is not assignable to type '(key: string) => string'.
      Type 'string | number | string[]' is not assignable to type 'string'.
        Type 'number' is not assignable to type 'string'.
```

content-type just uses a type literal to cut out the part of `Response` that it cares about. Either it should update its type or change to requiring the full `Response` type, which it would need to import.

My feeling is that content-type definition should be adapted here as getHeader() may return something else then a string in general so the definition here matches better to the actual code.
For the content-type case getHeader() is always called with 'content-type' which should in real world code be either a string or undefined but not string[],...
I have fixed content-type and added linting.

Doesn't `format` use the same type as `parse` returns? If so, how come we need both `UrlObject` and `Url`? Won't the latter suffice?

Also, I would suggest renaming `Url` to `ParsedURL` to disambiguate it from `URL`

From node docu: `The value of urlObject.port is coerced to a string and appended to result`
So in fact everything convertible to string is accepted here (which would be `any`) but you will get a `string | null` from `parse()`.
In real world apps `string | number` is usually what is needed which is most likely the reason why noone complained yet.
There are several such places in node; e.a. you can set everything convertible to `string` as a http header.
I think the most general overload should go *last*, otherwise none of the later overloads will be reached.
I've been following the convention in other core modules, where the general case for EventEmitter functions is always placed first. I don't think there is an issue with later overloads being reached.
You're right, I think we special-case this for string overloads.
I don't think these `void` overloads are necessary; `void` could be just another `TResult`.
Ping @alvis

Sorry for the belated reply.

They are not overloads. In fact, they've different structure of return depending on whether `arg1` is passed to `fn`.

Got it. The reason of having another one is for the benefit of `result` in the callback function. Without the first declaration, typescript will suggest that the callback has two arguments instead of one, and the type of `result` is `{}`.
I think it should be `NodeJS.ErrnoException | null`.

ðŸ¤” After checking the definition of NodeJS.ErrnoException, I'm convinced that it should be the case. However, it seems like no one use `NodeJS.ErrnoException | null` in all other callback functions.

We can either correct all of them, or convert `ErrnoException` to a type which includes `null` as an alternative.
I think it would be better to add `| null` everywhere, because people may be using `NodeJS.ErrnoException` as a type already and expecting it to be an interface type.

I agree with @andy-ms. I expect node types were created before strictNullChecks was in place.
But I think such a change should be in a new PR. Maybe I will create one once CI for Node is stable again...
These all have the same type of value, shouldn't it just be the string indexer then?
I think it's better to leave them for documentation purposes. From type checker point of view it doesn't matter, but for human reader it should make it more clear what is expected usage.
Similar to `setTimeout`, `setImmediate` can also take a value.
See earlier comment.
See earlier comment.
I think this should be `_destroy(err: Error | null, (err: Error | null) => void)`.

At least the documentation does not specify `null` as a possible value for the first parameter.

For the callback type I tried to align this change with the signature of `_destroy` in other stream classes. If it was changed to the more specific type it should probably be reflected there as well for consistency.

To my understanding `_destroy()` gets called if `destroy()` is called. As parameter to `destroy()` is optional it may happen that `_destroy()` gets no Error object.
Node defaults to null in this case. see https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/1fe9b535a78a23a9549b544ec4a4f76614f45c5c/lib/internal/streams/destroy.js#L32

But you are right, the `_destroy()` for `Writeable` and `Duplex` are like your proposal so maybe it's better to keep them in sync to avoid confusion.
I think it should be `NodeJS.ErrnoException | null`.
I think it should be `NodeJS.ErrnoException | null`.
I think you are right, but all the other callbacks are declared this way so I kept the same style
ok fine with me. Maybe it's better to change them all via a separated PR.
Duplicate of #21768.
Maybe remove this, and make the `boolean` `parse` overload return `UrlParsedQuery | UrlStringQuery`?
seems `Url.url` is used at several other modules so I will keep it.
The description should probably be amended

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +4619,4623 @@     * If {to} isn't already absolute, {from} arguments are prepended in right to left order, until an absolute path is found. If after using all {from} paths still no absolute path is found, the current working directory is used as well. The resulting path is normalized, and trailing slashes are removed unless the path gets resolved to the root directory.
     *
     * @param pathSegments string paths to join.  Non-string arguments are ignored.
     */
    export function resolve(...pathSegments: string[]): string;

comments.body: I think there should be also a `closed: boolean` and `pending: boolean` (see https://nodejs.org/dist/latest/docs/api/http2.html#http2_http2stream_closed and https://nodejs.org/dist/latest/docs/api/http2.html#http2_http2stream_pending)
Done

Should we add a `TypedArray` alias in the meantime until typescript offers a built-in solution in one of their lib files?

> `type TypedArray = Int8Array | Uint8Array | Int16Array | Uint16Array | Int32Array | Uint32Array | Uint8ClampedArray | Float32Array | Float64Array;`
>
> -- [<cite>Microsoft/TypeScript#15402</cite>](https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/15402#issuecomment-297544403)

Is that going to cause re-definition issues when the built-in `TypedArray` becomes available? If so maybe it's better to either not include, or have a type with a different name. Since other places use `TypedArray` as well, it shouldn't be difficult to substitute all in a separate PR.
As long as it's not defined in the global scope, you should be okay.
https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/de0053cc3280bdf72c9010f383290f79120a1e98/doc/api/deprecations.md#dep0069-vmrunindebugcontextstring
is it really `any` here or should this be something like `{}` to avoid `null` and `undefined`?

I wrote "any" to match the definition of `write` on the stream. The [documentation](https://nodejs.org/api/stream.html#stream_writable_write_chunk_encoding_callback_1) also says `<any>`; I know of no reason it couldn't be null or undefined on an object-mode stream.

I have read here https://nodejs.org/dist/latest/docs/api/stream.html#stream_writable_write_chunk_encoding_callback that `null` is not allowed in object mode. But you are right the APIs should be symmetric.
Wait, `log` isn't `console.log`?
No, it wraps `console.log` and adds a timestamp. However, it's a soft deprecation (no runtime warning), but its marked "deprecated" in the docs.
Question just for interest: what is the reason to move this into `global` here?

https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/issues/25342

I'm working on build failures caused by 10.0.0 being pulled in as a transitive dependency and I wonder whether the decision to move these definitions into the global namespace is causing the collision here.

It was definitely made a global because `node` now places it into the global scope (which is problematic if node is in the same compilation as the `dom` lib), this really needs https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/pull/15780 (and for the `URL` constructor to be in its own lib) for it to be handled well.

@weswigham I'm apprehensive that even Microsoft/TypeScript#15780 will help since the WHATWG URL implementation has a subtly different API surface in the DOM vs. NodeJS. Rather, I think this will necessitate switching the definition of `URL` and `URLSearchParams` in DOM to use the same split interface (instance vs. constructor) approach we use for Object, Number, etc. so that the declarations can merge.
I'm reverting this specific change in #25356 for now.

I believe this same type of problem exists for `setTimeout`.

The implementation is subtly different in the DOM vs Node.js, specifically the return type. https://nodejs.org/dist/latest-v10.x/docs/api/timers.html

Somehow TypeScript is able to handle this scenario, right?

This is not for this PR, but I noticed that `__promisify__(hostname: string, rrtype?: "A" | ...)` prevents `__promisify__(hostname: string, rrtype?: string)` from ever matching a call like `__promisify__("host")`. I'm pretty sure that `rrtype` should not be optional in the first overload.
`of` is not a member of `Buffer`, it's available in `Buffer` via base `Uint8Array` so it should not be here.
Yeah; I just did a hotfix because a build failed because it couldn't find a definition of `Buffer.of`; so I added it.

I think the correct approach would be to create `BufferConstructor extends Uint8ArrayConstructor` but this wont work out of the box as the `from` methods are incompatible.
So most likely using your hotfix is best for now.
Usually I would state to add some comment in this but one more commit will result again in a CI nightmare which is not worth to do.
Could you explain why need to introduce new type definition instead of using `ArrayBufferView`, which covers the same types https://heycam.github.io/webidl/#common ?
~~Hmm. Maybe something wrong, but in [MDN docs](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/ArrayBufferView) `ArrayBufferView` also contains `DataView`~~
Yeah. The actual one checks against the string name of the prototype rather than eg `ArrayBuffer.isView()`.
